questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with constipation and anal bleeding. A mass is detected on digital rectal examination, prompting a CT with rectal contrast and a biopsy for suspected malignancy. Histopathological examination of the biopsy will confirm normal tissues of the anal canal as the transitional zone ( area of Pecten) is lined by which type of epithelium?

As a first-year resident in the Orthopaedics department, you observe a 15-year-old male presenting with frequent fractures every 3 months. Suspecting osteogenesis imperfecta type I, which type of collagen is involved in this disorder?
questions.explanation:
Type I

Type II

Type III

Type IV
  • Bone, tendon, ligament
  • Fibrocartilage (atypical cartilage) has a neurovascular bundle
  • Dermis (skin)
  • Old scar
  • Cartilage (hyaline, elastic)
  • Lymphoid organs (spleen, liver, lymph nodes)
  • Healing/ granulation tissue
  • Basal lamina/ membrane
  • Alport syndrome ( problem in type IV)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to OPD with complaints of headache after hitting her head accidentally with the wall while doing household chores. An MRI was ordered, which confirmed the presence of a blood clot in her great cerebral vein of Galen. An obstructed vein is a direct tributary of which of the following venous structures?

A 43-year-old male underwent a parotidectomy for a malignant lesion in the right parotid region. He now experiences loss of sensation while shaving. Which nerve could have been iatrogenically injured, causing this symptom?

A 37-year-old male presents with a sudden severe sore throat, left ear pain, voice change, and difficulty opening his mouth fully for the past 3 days. On examination, there is significant fluctuant erythematous swelling involving the left tonsil and drooling of saliva. Which nerve is responsible for the referred pain in the patient's ear?

A 33-year-old man underwent thyroidectomy . The nerve that accompanies the superior thyroid artery is damaged during the surgery . An injured nerve could result in a severe impairment of which of the following functions?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Laryngeal Mucosa Supply Till the vocal cord/ upper surface of VC: Internal LN. Below vocal cord/form lower surface of VC: Recurrent LN Laryngeal Mucosa on Vocal Cord Supplied by: Internal LN In Thoracic inlet syndrome: Lt recurrent laryngeal nerve is Involved
  • ➤ Laryngeal Mucosa Supply Till the vocal cord/ upper surface of VC: Internal LN. Below vocal cord/form lower surface of VC: Recurrent LN Laryngeal Mucosa on Vocal Cord Supplied by: Internal LN In Thoracic inlet syndrome: Lt recurrent laryngeal nerve is Involved
  • ➤ Till the vocal cord/ upper surface of VC: Internal LN. Below vocal cord/form lower surface of VC: Recurrent LN Laryngeal Mucosa on Vocal Cord Supplied by: Internal LN In Thoracic inlet syndrome: Lt recurrent laryngeal nerve is Involved
  • ➤ Till the vocal cord/ upper surface of VC: Internal LN.
  • ➤ Below vocal cord/form lower surface of VC: Recurrent LN
  • ➤ Laryngeal Mucosa on Vocal Cord Supplied by: Internal LN
  • ➤ In Thoracic inlet syndrome: Lt recurrent laryngeal nerve is Involved

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is taken to the emergency room because of dyspnea, palpitations, and shortness of breath. A Doppler examination of the heart reveals an atrial septal defect (ASD). This malformation is generally the result of incomplete closure of which of the following embryonic structures?

A 40-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to persistent hiccups post-cholecystectomy. Suspected abdominal abscess irritation of the diaphragm is causing this. Which nerves carry pain fibers from the central part of the diaphragm's lower surface?

A 13-year-old boy is admitted to the emergency room after losing control in a motorcycle race in which several other drivers ran him over. The physical exam shows multiple cuts and bruises on the left forearm. The left wrist, fingers, and thumb cannot be straightened, although the elbow can be straightened . There is sensory deficit at the side half of the back of the left hand . Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured?
Which of the following conditions would be a result of radial artery stenosis?

options.label: A
options.text: A marked decrease in the blood flow in the superficial palmar arterial arch

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased pulsation in the artery passing superficial to the flexor retinaculum

options.label: C
options.text: Ischemia of the entire extensor muscles of the forearm

options.label: D
options.text: A marked decrease in the blood flow in the princeps pollicis artery

questions.correct_answer: D. A marked decrease in the blood flow in the princeps pollicis artery

questions.text: A 42-year-old male, an alcoholic, was diagnosed with cholelithiasis. The surgeon explained to the patient about the risk of developing acute pancreatitis due to gallstones. Embryologically, the pancreas develops from two pancreatic buds, namely the ventral and dorsal buds. Which of the following part of the pancreas arise from the dorsal pancreatic bud?

options.label: A
options.text: Lower part of the head of the pancreas

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency department by her mother with complaints of accidental ingestion of a coin. The patient is also complaining of pain and pressure on his neck. The patient was posted for endoscopy, and endoscopic removal of the coin was done. The foreign body may get lodged in which of the following part of the structure involved in the patient's pathology?

options.label: B
options.text: Where it crosses the aortic arch

options.label: C
options.text: Where it is crossed by left bronchus

questions.correct_answer: A. At the level of cricopharyngeal
questions.explanation:
Constriction of esophagus

Vertebral level

Distance from upper incisors

Cricopharyngeal

C6

6”

Arch of aorta

T4

9”

Crossing of the left bronchus

T6

11”

Esophageal opening in the diaphragm

T10

15”

questions.text: A researcher is studying the membrane potential of a neuronal cell membrane. He discovers that the cell membrane is freely permeable to three ions, X, Y, and Z. At resting membrane potential, the respective equilibrium potentials of X and Y are – 30 mV and – 40 mV. He infuses a drug that blocks the permeability of Z. What will happen to the membrane potential if a drug is infused that can block the permeability of Z?
Which of the following can cause an increase in cardiac output?

Airway resistance is not constant. Airway resistance is markedly affected by changes in the diameter of the airways. Therefore, diseases affecting the respiratory tract can increase airway resistance. Which of the following factors increases the resistance of the airways?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased sympathetic stimulation of airway smooth muscle

questions.text: An experiment is being conducted on drug 'X' based on the phenomenon that when a drug is not actively secreted, and the reabsorption is negligible, the renal CL of a drug is often related to the renal glomerular filtration rate. Drugs are usually filtered through the glomerulus in a nonselective process if they are in a free, nonprotein-bound form. Which of the following is true for a substance "X," which has more renal clearance than the GFR?

options.label: A
options.text: “X” is only being reabsorbed by the tubules

options.label: B
options.text: “X” is being secreted by the tubules

options.label: C
options.text: “X” is being secreted as well as reabsorbed by the tubules

questions.correct_answer: B. “X” is being secreted by the tubules

questions.text: What is the underlying pathophysiological process responsible for short stature, obesity, craniofacial abnormalities, low blood sugar, and low serum IGF-1 levels despite elevated basal serum growth hormone levels?

options.label: C
options.text: Elevated levels of p lasma IGF-BP3

options.label: D
options.text: Normal levels of p lasma IGF-BP3

questions.text: Which of the following regions is devoid of myelin sheath in a normal peripheral nerve?
Which structure is least likely to be painfully stimulated by touching or pulling?

options.label: B
options.text: The dura overlying the postcentral gyrus

options.label: C
options.text: Branches of the middle meningeal artery that lie superficial to the dura over the postcentral gyrus

options.label: D
options.text: Branches of the middle cerebral artery that supply the postcentral gyrus

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct pairing of its nuclei and respective function?

options.label: A
options.text: Satiety center: lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus

options.label: B
options.text: Reward center: Ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus

options.label: C
options.text: Circadian rhythm: preoptic nuclei of the hypothalamus

options.label: D
options.text: Oxytocin secretion: paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus

questions.correct_answer: D. Oxytocin secretion: paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus
questions.explanation:
Function Hypothalamic Nuclei

Satiety center

Oxytocin Paraventricular nucleus
Circadian rhythm Suprachiasmatic nucleus

questions.text: Which specific nucleus, located slightly anterior and lateral to the cerebral aqueduct , is involved in the constriction of the pupil, the light reflex, and the accommodation reflex ?

Opioids are a commonly used analgesic that can exert their effects at various places in the CNS, including in the spinal cord and dorsal root ganglia. Interneurons that utilize the neurotransmitter enkephalin to inhibit afferent pain signals are most likely to be found in which region of the central nervous system?
questions.correct_answer: A. Dorsal horn of spinal cord
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Enkephalins are the natural opiate peptides recognized first in a pig’s brain. Derived from the precursor proenkephalin, these peptides are present in the nerve endings in many parts of the forebrain, substantia gelatinosa of the brainstem, spinal cord, and GI tract. Two types of enkephalins are known, leucine enkephalin (YGGFL) and methionine enkephalin (YGGFM). Interneurons in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord use enkephalin which inhibits pain transmission from tissues of the body. Interneurons are physically short neurons that form a connection between other neurons that are usually close together.
  • ➤ Enkephalins are the natural opiate peptides recognized first in a pig’s brain. Derived from the precursor proenkephalin, these peptides are present in the nerve endings in many parts of the forebrain, substantia gelatinosa of the brainstem, spinal cord, and GI tract. Two types of enkephalins are known, leucine enkephalin (YGGFL) and methionine enkephalin (YGGFM).
  • ➤ Interneurons in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord use enkephalin which inhibits pain transmission from tissues of the body.
  • ➤ Interneurons are physically short neurons that form a connection between other neurons that are usually close together.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man suddenly collapsed while standing, waiting for a bus. The rescue team arrives and finds that his BP is 90/60 mm Hg. After initial resuscitation by maintaining an IV line and fluid resuscitation, he is brought to the hospital to get investigated and managed on the line of shock. Low-pressure baroreceptors are involved in the regulation of blood volume. Which of the following is related to these receptors?

options.label: B
options.text: They do not provide efferent for thirst control

options.label: C
options.text: They are located in the carotid sinus

options.label: D
options.text: They do not affect vasopressin release

questions.correct_answer: A. They are all low-pressure receptors

questions.text: In which part of the digestive tract are Brunner's glands predominately located?
Which of the following TCA cycle enzymes is most likely to be affected by riboflavin deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Coenzyme Vitamin TCA cycle enzyme
Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) B1 (Thiamine)

α ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (also requires other 4 cofactors similar to Pyruvate dehydrogenase)
Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) B3 (Niacin)

Isocitrate dehydrogenase,

α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

Malate dehydrogenase
Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) B2 (Riboflavin)

Succinate dehydrogenase

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy suffering from congenital deficiency of muscle phosphorylase is getting examined by an ischemic forearm exercise test by squeezing a rubber ball. This patient would exhibit which one of the following as compared to a normal person performing the same test?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased blood glucose in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

options.label: C
options.text: Increased lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

options.label: D
options.text: Relatively decreased blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

questions.correct_answer: D. Relatively decreased blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

questions.text: A 3-year old male child presents with hepatomegaly and bilateral lenticular opacities. Laboratory examination revels normal blood glucose levels by GOD-POD assay but positive Benedict’s test in urine. Physician suspected it to be a case of galactosemia. Deficiency of which one of the following enzymes will cause such features.

A newborn is tested for phenylketonuria (PKU) using a blood sample taken from the umbilical cord . Based on the blood report, the newborn is declared negative for PKU, and the pediatrician imposes no dietary restrictions. The child is again brought to the pediatrician after 12 months . This time, the child is reported to have aggressive behavior and delayed milestones . Blood and urine tests for PKU are redone, and they are positive this time. Finally, a diagnosis of PKU is made. What is the most probable reason for misdiagnosis at birth in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Cord blood is not a good source of fetal blood

options.label: B
options.text: The Guthrie test used in diagnosis has low sensitivity

options.label: C
options.text: Maternal blood should have been used

options.label: D
options.text: The test was performed too early to be positive

questions.correct_answer: D. The test was performed too early to be positive

questions.text: A newborn presents with severe respiratory distress and has not gained proper weight during the past several weeks. Examination revealed muscle hypotonia and neurological problems and an extremely low level of acetyl CoA carboxylase in liver. The most likely reason for an infant's respiratory problems is:

A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency by her parents with complaints because lethargy, vomiting, and abdominal pain for 6 hours. History revealed severe polyuria, polydipsia, and polyphagia. One of the test tubes with a positive test for the urinary examination is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely source of compound showing a positive reaction in this patient:

Dideoxynucleotides are used for Sanger DNA sequencing technique. Whenever this nucleotide is added in to growing DNA chain, the chain elongation stops causing termination of DNA synthesis. This form the basis of this sequencing technique. Based on that knowledge we can deduce that a dideoxynucleotide does not contain:
What is the wavelength at which nucleic acids show maximum absorption of UV light ?

A family member in a TB-positive patient's house is exposed and found to give a positive tuberculin test (PPD) with a normal chest X-ray. He is placed on preventive 6-month isoniazid therapy and develops peripheral neuropathies. Which of the following vitamins can be prescribed for the treatment of neuropathies?

A 55-year-old man presents with mild liver disease, arthritis, fatigue, and grayish skin pigmentation. A highly elevated level of iron is observed in his liver biopsy report. Which of the following conditions will be most likely found in this patient?

A 69-year-old male known case of DM and HTN for five years presented with fever, fatigue, and weakness for one month. His past medical history was unremarkable. On physical examination, the patient had anaemia and massive splenomegaly. His lab investigations showed pancytopenia. His peripheral blood studies, including flow cytometry and peripheral smear examination, suggested the diagnosis of Hairy Cell Leukemia (HCL) confirmed by bone marrow biopsy and immunohistochemistry (IHC). Which of the following statements is supportive of the diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: The tumour cells express CD11c and CD103

options.label: D
options.text: The HCL cell is clover shaped

questions.correct_answer: B. The tumour cells express CD11c and CD103

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is being evaluated for chronic fatigue. She has a history of heavy menstrual periods since menarche and recalls frequent nosebleeds as a child. Her past medical history is otherwise insignificant, and she takes no medications. Laboratory studies show normal prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), platelet count and fibrinogen levels . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old lady presents with features of malabsorption and iron deficiency anaemia. She is vitally stable and afebrile. A duodenal histopathological biopsy was performed, which revealed complete villous atrophy. Which of the following antibodies is likely to be present?

A 23-year-old male presents to the OPD with complaints of joint pain, rash on face, palm and shin, and weight loss. There is radiographic evidence of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and interstitial lung disease . A lung biopsy gives findings similar to those shown in the figure. Which of the following is a major characteristic of this disorder?

options.label: B
options.text: Highest incidence in persons of Asian lineage

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman has an ovarian tumour removed. The surgical specimen is cystic and 10 cm in diameter. Black hair and sebaceous substances are discovered in the cystic cavity. A range of benign differentiated tissues, including skin, cartilage, brain, and mucinous glandular epithelium , are found on histologic inspection of the cyst wall. What is the diagnosis?

A 17-year-old girl comes to the hospital with chest pain and respiratory distress. A prominent pansystolic heart murmur and a prominent third heart sound are heard on cardiac auscultation. The patient expires despite intense supportive measures. At autopsy, microscopic findings are as shown in a given image. The mechanism of developing a given disease is which of the following?

A 68-year-old Caucasian man with a history of smoking of twenty-five pack-year presented in the outpatient department with complaints of new-onset dyspnea on exertion and abdominal pain . He had a history of prolonged neonatal jaundice . On physical examination, the patient had a barrel chest , diminished lung breath sounds, and a swollen abdomen with hepatomegaly. Chest x-ray shows hyper-inflated lungs widened intercostal spaces and a low diaphragm. The abdomen ultrasound report showed a nodular liver surface. Based on the above history and clinical findings, which of the following is the most likely diagno sis?

A 62-year-old male presented to the emergency department with complaints of the right upper quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and high-grade fever . Physical examination reveals signs of jaundice . He has no history of pancreatitis or any alcohol or drug abuse . His vitals show mild tachycardia with normal blood pressure. Laboratory investigations revealed leukocytosis, normal haemoglobin, increased direct bilirubin, normal serum indirect bilirubin, and increased alkaline phosphatase . Which of the following is the appropriate diagnosis?

A 27-year-old female presents to a fertility clinic to discuss her inability to conceive despite an active effort to conceive for more than two years. She denies using any protective equipment or contraceptive medication. She mentions that her menstrual cycles are regular but have recently been more painful than usual. She states a history of unusual pain during intercourse for more than a year with no associated post-coital or heavy menstrual bleeding. Physical examination reveals focal tenderness on the vaginal examination, immobility of the cervix on manipulation and palpation of the left adnexal mass. A transvaginal ultrasound scan reveals a 6cm nodule on the surface of the left ovary. A diagnostic laparoscopy reveals a large nodule on her left ovary and multiple small red-blue nodules over the surface of her ovaries and uterine ligaments. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 45-year-old female underwent hysterectomy for dysfunctional uterine bleeding. Following are the gross and histological findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 56-year-old female comes to the outdoor patient department with presenting complaints of fever, myalgia and arthralgia for 6 days. The patient has no history of concomitant respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms. Her physical examination is normal, and she has been treated for viral fever. However, her complete blood count reveals that she has pancytopenia (total white cell count of 2.9 × 109/L, neutrophil count of 1.1 × 109/L, Hb of 10.6 g/ dL, and Plt of 110 × 109/L) despite her recovery from viral fever. Subsequently, investigations are done to identify pancytopenia. Bone marrow aspiration and trephine biopsy (BMAT) show normal marrow cellularity. Serum vitamin B12 and folate levels are normal. On further investigation, free T4 37.8 pmol/L, TSH < 0.01 mU/L, detection of anti-microsomal antibodies, anti-thyroglobulin antibodies and Thyroid Stimulating Immunoglobulins are seen. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in histology?

options.label: A
options.text: Sheets of Polygonal cells in an amyloid stroma

options.label: C
options.text: Empty appearing nuclei with central clearing

options.label: D
options.text: A pale colloid in the follicular lumen with scalloped margins

questions.correct_answer: D. A pale colloid in the follicular lumen with scalloped margins

questions.text: A 47-year-old male with no previous medical history presents to his physician complaining of episodic headaches, sweating, palpitations, and tremors. The symptoms started a few years ago, have become more frequent, and can last between a few seconds and an hour. The episodes often occur when the patient is stressed or during exercises. He has no history of serious illnesses, hospitalizations, or trauma. He is not on any medications. Radiological imaging was done, which is shown below. Which of the following is the least likely feature of the most probable diagnosis?

A 32-year-old female developed symptoms of amenorrhea about one and a half years after she stopped nursing her baby; she had no resumption of menses. Her gynaecologist told her she had Polycystic ovary syndrome (after five successful pregnancies without assistance). She then developed acne and facial hair about 6 months later. Subsequently, she developed back pain and was found to have a compression fracture of her lumbar spine. Imaging shows a decreased size of the adrenal gland. . What will be the most common cause of the probable diagnosis?

A 60-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and coronary artery disease presented to emergency complaining of approximately 1–2 weeks of neck pain radiating to his chest. The pain is associated with movement, particularly when he moves his head and neck. Other than the presenting symptoms, his review of symptoms was negative. His blood pressure was 126/67 mm Hg, and his pulse was 88 beats/min. Chest CT revealed no significant cardiac or pulmonary disease. However, a large ill-defined 4 cm right thyroid nodule was noted, associated with tracheal deviation at the thoracic inlet. TSH was normal at 1.18 mIU/ml. Hemithyroidectomy was done, and the H&E stain was positive for the nest of tumour cells and calcitonin shown below. RET proto-oncogene is associated with the most probable diagnosis discussed above:

A 45-year-old patient presented with neurological deficits and seizures. Imaging showed a lesion in the temporal lobe. Biopsy was taken from the lesion, and neural tissue was sent for histological examination (microscopy shown below). Based on the characteristic histological features, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old male presented with slurring of speech and right-side weakness of both upper and lower limbs. CT head revealed the presence of an infarct in the brain. Disease or infarction of neurological tissue causes it to be replaced by which of the following?

A 36-year old female patient is evaluated for gram negative septicemia. The patient’s medical records reveals that she has earlier experienced an episode of anaphylaxis leading to shock after the administration of penicillin V. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient?

A 25-year-old male patient presents at the clinic with complaints of foul-smelling white discharge from the urethra. He also has burning micturition for 10 days. He also gave a history of intercourse with a commercial sex worker 7 days prior to the onset of all symptoms. Gram staining shows gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this condition?

A 48-year-old male undergoing Whipple’s procedure suddenly becomes rigid . His temperature rises to 104º F . The anaesthetist identifies it as a case of malignant hyperthermia. He starts the treatment with a skeletal muscle relaxant . Which of the following describes the correct mechanism of action for the skeletal muscle relaxant?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduces acetylcholine release from motor nerve endings

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibits the generation of muscle action potential

options.label: D
options.text: Reduces calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in the muscle fibre

questions.correct_answer: D. Reduces calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in the muscle fibre

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presented in the OPD with complaints of excessive thirst. He also reports has polyuria and polyphagia. He suspects it could be diabetes mellitus and orders fasting blood sugar, postprandial blood sugar & HbA1c. The HbA1c was about 12% , and the blood sugar values were over 240. He decides to start the patient on subcutaneous insulin therapy and educate the patient regarding the same. What is the mechanism of action of the therapy prescribed?

A 51-year-old patient visits the clinic again, expressing gastric irritation and diarrhea, despite recurrent duodenal ulcers and multiple treatments. After a secretin stimulation test shows elevated serum gastrin levels, which medication would the doctor prescribe to manage this condition?

A couple is presenting to you for a consultancy. They are planning a trekking experience in the Himalayas. The wife had previously experienced nausea and dizziness when she went for a trek in Skardu. Which of the following medications would you let her take to avoid developing headache, nausea, dizziness, and difficulty breathing ?
Which of the following is the mechanism of action of a statin drug?
Which of the following drugs can likely worsen myocardial ischemia in a patient with angina?

A 24-year-old female is brought to the physician by her mother with complaints of bradykinesia and resting tremors for five days. The mother of the patient further gives a history that the wedding of the patient was called off due to personal reasons, pushing her into a pile of stress . At times, the patient was noted to have violent episodes. After consultation with a psychiatrist, she was diagnosed with schizophrenia . The psychiatrist prescribed haloperidol for the control of the symptoms . A few weeks post-drug initiation, the patient developed these symptoms. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Which of the following would be the best to treat the patient’s current symptoms?

A few Doctors Without Borders physicians on a 6-month African village posting encounter a pale foreigner complaining of extreme fatigue since arrival. He's a diabetic on insulin with controlled bronchial asthma. Despite malaria prophylaxis, he struggles with food adjustment and erratic blood glucose. If suspecting a pharmacogenetic condition, what might explain his current state?

A 15-year-old girl arrived at the ER after ingesting 15 tablets of an unknown drug, causing altered mental status, rapid breathing, and vomiting. To treat drug toxicity, various methods can remove the drug from the body, such as dialysis. Which drug, when toxic, is eliminated through urine acidification?

A 50-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with hypotension, shortness of breath, swollen feet, and fatigue for the last day. He is a known case of ischemic heart disease. The patient also reports a history of snake bite six hours back. A clinicopathological conference is planned, and the same patient is discussed in the case study by a team of doctors, including a physician and a microbiologist. The microbiologist is asked about sterilizing heat-sensitive liquids like serum, vaccines, antisera, enzymes, and antibiotic solutions used in this patient. Which of the following best fixes heat labile keys in this case?
questions.explanation:
Depth filters

Membrane filters

Air filters

  • Porous filters [metal polymer with random mats]

  • Examples:

      • Candle filters

      • Unglazed porcelain filters

      • Seitz filter

      • Sintered glass filter

  • Most widely used filters for bacterial filtration

  • Made up of cellulose acetate, cellulose nitrate and polycarbonate

  • Pore size:

    • 0.22 µ → most common used

    • 0.45 µ → retains coliforms

    • 0.8 µ → retains airborne microorganisms

  • Use → to sterilize sugar, sera & antibiotic solution.

  • HEPA [high-efficiency particulate air] filter→ removes 99.97% of particles having a size of 0.3µ or more.

  • ULPA [ultra low particulate/penetration] → removes 99.999% of dust, pollen, and moulds.

    • Control → Brevundimonas diminuta & Serratia marcescens

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of repeated episodes of diarrhoea and fever for 1 week. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. The doctor sent the patient for stool examination and culture in the microbiology laboratory, which revealed a salmonella infection. In the laboratory, what screening procedure is used to differentiate the organism involved in the patient's pathology from other Enterobacteriaceae?
questions.explanation:
Lactose fermenters Non lactose fermenters

Escherichia

Klebsiella

Enterobacter

Other members of the Enterobacteriaceae family

including salmonella and shigella.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with fever, weight loss, and cough for several days. He is found to be HIV positive, and hepatomegaly is seen on examination. Sputum culture on SDA and staining reveal the fungus shown in the figure below. Which of the following fungus is the causative agent for this condition?

A 25-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of fever, loose motion and nausea for 2 days. He further gives a history of foul-smelling fatty stools. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. Analysis of stool on wet mount shows motile protozoa without RBCs and pus cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old lady brings her two-year-old unimmunized child to a child specialist. The baby has suffered from high-grade fever, cough, runny nose, and watery eyes for 5 days. The mother also gives a history of rash starting behind the ear pinna a day before coming to the hospital. On examination, the baby has normal weight and height according to age, his eyes are watery, and maculopapular rashes are seen on the abdomen and trunk region. What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?

A 38-year-old woman comes to the emergency department physician because of progressive pain and swelling of her wrists and hands for the past two months. Her hands are stiff in the morning; the stiffness decreases as she starts her chores. She also reports early-morning neck pain at rest for the past three weeks. Tenderness of the wrists, second, third, and fourth metacarpophalangeal joints; a range of motion is limited by pain. The doctor sent her sample for immunoglobulin testing to the microbiology laboratory. Which of the following is true about the classes of immunoglobulins?

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with cellulitis two days after he is bitten by his cat. What is the most likely dominant organism involved in the infection?
questions.explanation:
Option 1

Bartonella, is the causative agent of cat scratch fever and is less common in bites.

Features of Bartonella:

Can be cultured on normal culture media

  • B. bacilliformis → causes OROYA FEVER
  • B. henselae → caused Cat Scratch Disease and Bacillary Angiomatosis (common in HIV positive patients).

Bacillary Angiomatosis: Refer to the image below.

  • B. quintana → Causes TRENCH FEVER and Bacillary Angiomatosis (fewer cases).
Option 2

Calymmatobacterium granulomatis: causes a sexually transmitted infection, granuloma inguinale (or donovanosis).

  • Small,painless nodules appear after about 10–40 days of the contact with the bacteria.
  • Later, the nodules burst, creating open, fleshy, oozing lesions.
  • Site: Shaft of the penis, the labia, or the perineum
  • Diagnosis :Painless,"beefy-red ulcer" with a characteristic rolled edge of granulation tissue.
  • Wright Giemsa stain:Donovan bodies- rod-shaped, oval organisms that can be seen in the cytoplasm of mononuclear phagocytes or histiocytes in tissue samples.
Option 3

Pasteurella multocida is a dominant organism in Cat's mouth.
Option 4 Toxoplasma: associated with cats but transmitted by their faeces, not bites.

A 30-year-old man has been arrested by the police on charges of stalking a female friend. In the complaint, she alleges that he had followed her home after office hours and had also been threatening to hurt her if she did not accept his marriage proposal. What does the law refer to as stalking if this was the man's first offence?
questions.explanation:
IPC 354 Assault of criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty
IPC 354 A Sexual harassment and punishment for sexual harassment
IPC 354 B Assault or use of criminal force on to woman with intent to disrobe
IPC 354 C Voyeurism: Any man who watches, or captures the image of a woman engaging in a private act in circumstances where she would usually have the expectation of not being observed
IPC 354 D

Stalking: Any man who

  1. Follows a woman and contacts, or attempts to contact such woman to foster personal interaction repeatedly despite a clear indication of disinterest by such woman; or
  2. Monitors the use by a woman of the internet, email or any other form of electronic communication,
  • Punishable with
    • Imprisonment up to 3 years and a fine (cognizable and bailable)
    • Imprisonment up to 5 years and fine for subsequent offence (cognizable and non-bailable)

questions.text: The doctor who had treated the victim for the gun shot injury was summoned with a Subpoena to testify in court with the relevant medical documentation. What category of the document does a subpoena fall under?
questions.explanation:
Summon/Subpoena
· Other Name: Subpoena (Sub: Under, Poena: Penalty)
· Summon is a document given to the witness.
· In this document time, date, and place are mentioned.
· After giving this form if the witness has not come to the court, then the witness should pay the penalty. Hence it is known as Subpoena.
· Summon/Subpoena is classified into two.
o Subpoena AD Testification
  • AD: Attend
  • Testification: Give evidence.
  • It is used for the common witness.
o Subpoena Duces Tecum
  • Duces: Document
  • Tecum: Take the report to the court.
  • It is used for the expert witness.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the OPD with complaints of shortness of breath, swelling of legs, fatigue, palpitations, dizziness and episodes of fainting. He is a chronic alcoholic. On examination, a dicrotic pulse is found on palpation, and a pansystolic murmur is heard on auscultation. ECHO is done, and a diagnosis of Dilated Cardiomyopathy is made. The following procedure is done as a part of the treatment, whose image is shown below. Which of the following is this procedure?
Investigation of choice in COPD?
questions.explanation:
Type of COPD Description
Chronic Bronchitis - Characterized by chronic inflammation of the bronchial tubes (airways).
  - Excessive mucus production, leading to cough with sputum production.
  - Often associated with recurrent respiratory infections.
Emphysema - Involves damage to the alveoli (air sacs) in the lungs.
  - Loss of lung elasticity and reduced ability to exhale air effectively.
  - Leads to air trapping and increased work of breathing.
Mixed COPD - Some individuals may have features of both chronic bronchitis and emphysema.
  - Commonly referred to as "mixed" or "overlap" COPD.
Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency-Related COPD - Caused by a genetic deficiency of alpha-1 antitrypsin, an enzyme that protects the lungs from damage.
  - Can result in early-onset COPD, especially in non-smokers.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male comes to the neurology department with proximal muscle weakness . The patient is also affected by respiratory difficulty. He has been drinking since he was 25 years of age. The patient is non-diabetic and non-hypertensive. His blood pressure is 135/90 mmHg, and his pulse is 65/min. Physical examination reveals the drooping of eyelids . Lab value suggests antibodies against postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors. Which of the following statement is mostly associated with this patient ?
questions.correct_answer: B. Muscle movement worsens with exercise

questions.text: A 28- year - old female came to the hospital. She was undergoing treatment for SLE and came for a follow-up. A urine lab test was taken on lab investigation. There is proteinuria. You suspect renal involvement, for which a biopsy was done, which shows a wire loop appearance without glomerular proliferation. What is this class of lupus nephritis called?

A 25-year-old male came to your OPD to quit alcohol consumption. He has drinks daily for the last 5 years. His consumption is 2-3 beers daily and around 8-10 beers on weekends. He never drinks & drives and never misses his work. But he had hung over in the office after weekends. In the last few months, he had reported a few blackouts due to binge drinking. Which laboratory tests will you perform on this patient to identify heavy alcohol consumption?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ MCHC is calculated by multiplying the haemoglobin result from the CBC panel by 100 and then dividing by the hematocrit result.
  • ↳ The reference range for MCHC in adults is 33.4–35.5 grams per deciliter (g/dL).
  • ↳ If your MCHC value is below 33.4 grams per deciliter, you have low MCHC. Low MCHC values occur if you have anaemia due to iron deficiency. It can also indicate thalassemia. This is an inherited blood disorder in which you have fewer red blood cells and less haemoglobin present in your body. Learn more about low MCHC and its possible causes.
  • ↳ If your MCHC value is above 35.5 grams per deciliter, you have high MCHC.

questions.text: A forty year old male is brought to the emergency department by his neighbour. The patient complains of severe abdominal pain , which radiates to the back. The neighbour states that the patient is an alcoholic. The patient is admitted with the suspicion of acute pancreatitis. A few hours after admission, the patient starts vomiting and feels dizzy while standing. On examination, he has severe tenderness in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen and decreased bowel sounds. A bluish discolouration is noticed around his umbilicus. Further examinations would show which of the following findings.

options.label: A
options.text: A CT of the abdomen is likely to show severe necrotizing pancreatitis

options.label: B
options.text: Abdominal plain film is likely to show pancreatic calcification

questions.correct_answer: A. A CT of the abdomen is likely to show severe necrotizing pancreatitis

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to your clinic with his son complaining of chest pain with exertion . He has had this pain for the past few weeks, which occurs only after walking and is relieved when he sits down or takes a break. He is a long-time smoker and has smoked 2 packs-per-day for the past 30 years. His son tells you that 5 years ago, he was admitted to the same hospital for myocardial infarction (MI) . His heart rate is 72 beats/min, and his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. An ECG was performed, which is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

A 35-year-old female is brought to the hospital with her sister due to a persistent depressed mood. She also experienced low energy levels, negative thoughts, poor sleep, and increased appetite for the last 1 month. She was also hospitalized 3 years ago for symptoms of aggressive behaviour, overspending, and decreased sleep. She is a non-smoker and nonalcoholic. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

A 19–year–old male presents to the psychiatric emergency due to extreme restlessness, fidgetiness, and irritation for 1 week. It is associated with an inability to sit quietly. He is a known case of schizophrenia and is taking 20mg of haloperidol. Which of the following is the most effective treatment for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in the dose of haloperidol

questions.explanation:
Extrapyramidal Effects

Clinical features

Pharmacotherapy

Acute dystonia

Sudden sustained contraction of the neck, mouth, tongue, and eye muscles presenting as:

  • Oculogyric crisis, ocular muscles spasm, and opisthotonos
  • Torticollis
  • Laryngospasm
  • Grimacing

Earliest to develop. Occurs within days of drug usage.

Anticholinergic drugs:

  • Benztropine
  • Diphenhydramine

Acute akathisia
  • Constant purposeless involuntary movement from one place to another.
  • Most common EPS.
  • Occurs within days to weeks
  • Propranolol
  • Lorazepam
  • Benztropine

Tardive dyskinesia

Gradual onset after prolonged therapy (>6 months). Usually presents after years of treatment.

Dyskinesia of the mouth, face trunk, and extremities causing:

  • chewing and sucking movements
  • grimacing
  • choreoathetoid movements
  • Deutetrabenazine
  • Valbenazine

Malignant neuroleptic syndrome

Most serious side effect. Presents as:

  • Hyperthermia
  • Severe muscular rigidity and dystonia
  • Akinesia
  • Mutism
  • Fluctuating level of consciousness
  • Agitation
  • Tachycardia
  • High blood pressure

Laboratory findings include:

  • Increased WBC count
  • Increased level of CPK
  • Increased level of liver enzymes
  • Increased levels of plasma myoglobin and myoglobinuria
  • Occasionally renal failure
  • Immediately stop antipsychotics
  • Medically cool the patient
  • Monitor vital signs
  • Dantrolene (skeletal muscle relaxant)
  • Bromocriptine or Amantadine

Drug-induced parkinsonism

Gradual onset tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

Occurs within weeks to months
  • Benztropine
  • Amantadine

questions.text: A 41-year-old executive believes that the company's management has denied her promotion by fabricating reports about her competence and forging her signature on key documents to incriminate her. She goes to the police station and files a complaint, as well as a request for security. There is no problem in managing her job and household activities. She has been experiencing these ideas for the last 2 months and is referred to a psychiatrist for further evaluation. W hat is the diagnosis of this patient?

A 40-year-old man presents to a casualty with a history of regular and heavy use of alcohol for 10 years and morning drinking for one year. The last alcohol intake was 3 days back. There is no history of head injury or seizures. On examination, there is no icterus, signs of hepatic encephalopathy, or focal neurological signs. The patient has coarse tremors, visual hallucinations, and disorientation to time. Which of the following is the best medicine to be prescribed for such a patient?

A 45-year-old female presents to the OPD with a lump in her left breast. On examination, a 4 cm mass is noted in her left breast, with the left axillary lymph nodes fixed and matted . Overlying breast skin is normal, with no edema, swelling, or ulceration . No metastasis is seen on imaging. Which of the following is the most appropriate management method?

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with a lump in her left breast that she noticed one month ago. She has no family history of breast cancer . The mass is rubbery, mobile, and non-tender to palpation. There are no overlying skin changes or axillary lymphadenopathy . Ultrasound shows a 2-cm round cyst with smooth margins and no internal septations or solid components . Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient’s condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Aspiration of the cyst with cytologic analysis

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman complaints of fever and anterior neck pain that had persisted for more than one month . Lab findings indicate low TSH, elevated free T4 and T3.FNAC showed follicular destruction and giant cell formation . What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Subacute thyroiditis

Acute thyroiditis

Tubercular lymphadenitis

Hashimoto's thyroiditis

Painful

Severe pain

Painful/ painless

Painless

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to surgery OPD with a complaint of swelling in the front of the neck for the last 7 months. Her neck examination reveals a swelling in the midline of the neck with multiple nodules, which moves with deglutition. Her clinical features and laboratory investigation suggest multinodular goiter. She has been scheduled for a total thyroidectomy. Which of the following statements about the complications of thyroidectomy is true?

questions.text: A 62-year-old female presented to the clinic with nausea, vomiting, muscle weakness, fatigue, confusion, oliguria, 10 kg weight loss, and back pain at night . A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic reported right upper quadrant discomfort and audible bruit on examination. AFP was more than 20 mg/mL , with arterial enhancement on CT. Which of the following statement is most appropriate regarding treatment options for the diagnosis?

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents to the OPD with complaints of purple spots on her body and frequent nose and gum bleeding episodes. On probing her history further, it was found that she hasa known case of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura and has been on steroid treatment for two months. On examination, the patient has a non-palpable purpura with gingival bleeding. Her platelet count is 8000/cu.mm. The patient is taken in for elective splenectomy . questions.explanation:
Complications of Splenectomy

Pulmonary complications

  • Left lower lobe atelectasis: A most common complication
  • Pleural effusion
  • Pneumonia

Thromboembolic complications:

  • DVT
  • Portal vein thrombosis

Hemorrhagic complications

  • Subphrenic hematoma

DVT prophylaxis is roughly recommended

  • In patients with hemolytic anemia or myeloproliferative disorders & splenomegaly, the thrombotic risk is heightened, particularly the risk of portal vein thrombosis

Changes in blood

  • Howell Jolly bodies and siderocytes
  • Leukocytosis and increased platelet count

Infectious complications

  • Subphrenic abscess
  • Wound infection

Pancreatic complications

  • Pancreatitis
  • Pseudocyst
  • Pancreatic fistula

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication of appendectomy in the early postoperative period?

A 29-year-old woman with anorexia nervosa-binge eating/purging type (AN-BP) was admitted to your hospital for the c/o abdominal pain radiating to the back. According to her medical history, she had initiated dieting after entering college at the age of 18. Initially, she practiced only dietary restrictions but gradually began self-induced vomiting. Based on the medical history she provided, her weight (50 kg) decreased gradually and was 40 kg by the time she got married at 22. During this time, she had begun consuming a commercially available laxative. She was diagnosed with AN on a visit to a nearby mental clinic but refused hospitalization. Throughout this period, the patient continued to restrict her diet and abuse laxatives. You transfer the patient to the radiology department for a routine USG which revealed calculi in the renal pelvis of both kidneys. The most probable type of stone to develop in this patient is:

options.label: A
options.text: Straightening of the penis – Balanoplasty – Urethroplasty

options.label: C
options.text: Straightening of the penis – Urethroplasty – Balanoplasty

questions.text: A 72-year-old female came to the medical OPD with elevated blood pressure and type II diabetes mellitus. options.label: B

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a known case of esophageal cancer presented to the surgical outpatient department for his elective esophagectomy . A 55-year-old male presents to the hospital with complaints of severe back pain. He gives no history of any other abnormalities. He has no history of any chronic illness. A 25-year-old female presents to the office with complaints of burning pain in her hands for the past many months. He also complains of numbness, tingling, and burning. options.label: C

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented to the emergency with a complaint of fever and increasing pain in the right iliac fossa for one day. Multigravida

> 20hours

>14 hr

< 1 cm/hr

Phase of Labor Description Duration (Approximate)
Latent Phase (Early Labor) - The initial phase of labor. Variable

  - Contractions may begin, but they are usually mild and irregular.  
  - The woman may experience backache, cramps, or a show (mucus discharge).  
Active Phase - Cervical dilation progresses more rapidly. 6-12 hours (approx.)
  - Contractions become more intense, frequent, and regular.  
  - Cervix dilates from around 4 cm to 10 cm.  
  - The woman may experience increased discomfort and a strong urge to push.  
Transition Phase - The final phase before the pushing stage. 30 minutes to 2 hours
  - Cervix completes dilation (reaches 10 cm).  
  - Contractions may be very intense and frequent.  
  - The woman may feel exhausted and overwhelmed.  
  - Nausea, shivering, and emotional changes may occur.  
Pushing (Second Stage) - The phase of active pushing to deliver the baby. Variable
  - The woman actively pushes during contractions to help the baby move down the birth canal.  
  - This stage ends with the baby's delivery.  
Placental Delivery (Third Stage) - The delivery of the placenta (afterbirth). Generally within 30 minutes after the baby's birth.
  - Contractions continue to help expel the placenta.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant female (gravida 1, para 0) at 32 weeks of gestation has come to the hospital for regular follow-up. She is diagnosed with gestational diabetes at 26 weeks of gestation. Her Hb1c is 6.8%. Her fundal height is found to be 36 cm, and her abdominal skin appears excessively stretched and shiny. Her previous antenatal USG reports were normal. What could be the most probable diagnosis?

A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department complaining of fever and lower abdominal pain for the last 1 day. She delivered a preterm boy of 33 weeks gestation 2 days ago via cesarean delivery. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals uterine tenderness and purulent lochia. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

A 23-year-old female was evaluated in the postpartum unit 2 hours after delivery with hypotension, tachycardia and vaginal bleeding. The uterus is enlarged and boggy. She receives oxytocin during the third stage of labour. Oxytocin is a uterotonic. Uterotonics are drugs that stimulate uterine contractions. About uterotonics, all of the following statements are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: Oxytocin sensitivity is increased during delivery.

options.label: B
options.text: Prostaglandins may be given for inducing abortion during the second trimester.

options.label: C
options.text: Lactation and genital stimulation enhances oxytocin release

options.label: D
options.text: Oxytocin is used for inducing abortion in the first trimester

questions.correct_answer: D. Oxytocin is used for inducing abortion in the first trimester

questions.text: An 18-year-old primigravida, at 30 weeks of gestation, comes to the outpatient department for a routine antenatal check-up. On ultrasound with antenatal doppler, her fetal parameters correspond to 30 weeks, and the umbilical artery shows an S/D ratio of 2.8. She is advised to continue with her prenatal supplements and daily fetal movement counts. The patient returns after 4 weeks, and her ultrasound is repeated. She has no high-risk factors and is perceiving fetal movements well. What is the S/D ratio in the umbilical artery expected at this visit?

options.label: D
options.text: Constant at 2.8 with a diastolic notch

questions.text: A 29-year-old married woman presents with the complaint of infertility. She is unable to conceive, has regular menstrual cycles, and has mild dysmenorrhea. Her pelvic scan shows an intramural fibroid of 3 cm and a follicular ovarian cyst. A tubal assessment by HSG is normal as well. The husband's semen analysis is normal, and so is his hormonal profile. Which of these is the most likely cause of infertility?
Which type of ovarian tumor is most likely to cause torsion?

A 55-year-old post-menopausal woman presents to the gynaecology department with complaints of pruritic white lesions on the vulva over the last 6 months. A punch biopsy of a representative area is obtained after the examination. She is suspected of having Lichen sclerosis. Which of the following histologic findings is consistent with the diagnosis of the patient's current condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Blunting or loss of Rete pegs

options.label: D
options.text: Increase in the number of cellular layers in the epidermis

questions.correct_answer: A. Blunting or loss of Rete pegs

questions.text: A 38- year woman operated on a lower segment uterine fibroid. She had an uneventful surgery. Post-operatively the urine output decreased, up to 20 ml/hr. Rapid IV fluid infusions were given with an injection of Lasix, and output increased to 70 ml/hr. The urine was clear. A patient complained of flank pain which was gradually progressing. What is the most common cause of such presentation?

A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with her husband due to vomiting, constipation and abdominal distention. A Plain X-ray of the abdomen reveals multiple air-fluid levels. Vaginal examination shows a loop of extra tissue resembling the intestine protruding from the cervix. Which of the following history must be present in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: B. History of dilatation and curettage (D &C)

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents to the maternity emergency with active labor at the 38th week of gestation. The patient is shifted to the labor room and is being managed on escalating doses of oxytocin. The patient's pulse is 98/min, blood pressure is 110/70, respiratory rate is 18/min, and temperature is 37.2 C. Pelvic examination shows a fully dilated cervix and vertex positioned above station 0 with caput. CTG shows persistent decelerations after each contraction. Which of the following is the next best step in managing this patient?

A 37-year-old woman presents to the hospital with a history of missed periods and a positive pregnancy test. She has been on oral anticoagulation after a valve replacement surgery 1 year back. After confirming viability, the doctor switches her to heparin for the first trimester and returns to warfarin after 12 weeks. What should be the course of anticoagulation in the third trimester?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue with warfarin till delivery as embryogenesis is already over

questions.text: A 30-year-old infertile patient presents with chronic lower abdominal pain, congestive dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia. She has regular cycles and today is the 25th day of her period. On vaginal examination, there is pelvic tenderness and nodularity in the posterior fornix. The most probable diagnosis is?
A patient with peritoneal endometriotic implants is given medroxyprogesterone acetate for management. What is the mechanism of action involved here?
When planning ART (Artificial Reproductive Techniques) cycles for couples, which factor is not a concern for ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS)?

A 22-year-old woman presents to the doctor with complaints of irregular cycles for a few months. Her cycles are 35-45 days long, lasting for 3 to 4 days with mild to moderate blood flow. There is, however, no passage of clots and no dysmenorrhea. Which of the following accurately describes this condition?

A 6-year-old male child was brought to the hospital with a complaint of fever associated with abdominal pain . On examination, the patient presents with right upper quadrant tenderness with hepatomegaly. CT abdomen reveals the below-depicted image. Which of the following is the most common organism responsible for this infection?
questions.explanation:
Organisms

                          Infections

Staphylococcus aureus

Pyogenic liver abscess, food poisoning, skin and wound infections.

Haemophilus influenzae

Meningitis, bacteremia and pneumonia, epiglottitis

Entamoeba Histolytica

Amoebic liver abscess and dysentery

Klebsiella pneumoniae

Atypical pneumonia (especially in alcoholics).

Bloodstream infections, wound or surgical site infections, and meningitis.

questions.text: A 4-month-old male baby presents to the pediatrician with persistent diarrhea. The patient had a history of recurrent attacks of pneumonia and otitis media, for which he had to be hospitalized. No live vaccines were administered to the patient. Further history reveals the diagnosis of severe combined immunodeficiency. Which of the following features is associated with the condition of this patient?

A 2.5-year-old male child was admitted to the pediatric department with complaints of recurrent vomiting episodes and jaundice for 1 year. On examination, the patient has hepatomegaly. Patient labs show hypoglycemia. These episodes seem to have a relationship with the intake of sweet food. The mother also provides additional information about the child's aversion to sugary foods. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this child?

A 7-year-old child is brought and admitted by an intern who was on her rotation to Kolkata. She visited the family (strictly vegetarian) allotted to her for the first time. She proceeded with her framed question and marked the family as having low socioeconomic status according to the Udai Parikh scale. The child also looked emaciated and lethargic . On examination, hepatomegaly is present. His weight for age was < -3 Z score, MUAC, 115 mm. What else is to be present in growth-retarded children for the diagnosis?

A 32-year-old multigravida is at 38 weeks of gestation; she is an unbooked case, and an intern is asked to take the lady's history. Her vitals are normal, and there is no specific history she remembers other than that she has diabetes. Oxytocin is given for labour induction, and an ultrasound is conducted to determine the baby's status. The family is informed regarding the complications their baby might have. What is the most specific congenital abnormality that this baby can have?

A neonate weighing 1.3 kg was born at 32 weeks of gestation and was transferred to the nursery for prematurity. After 1 hour, the nurse reports the infant is tachypneic with a heart rate of 150 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 76/min, a temperature of 95°F, and an oxygen saturation of 98%. His blood sugar level is normal, and he is not dehydrated. The lungs are clear with bilateral breath sounds, no murmur, and the X-ray chest is normal. Which of the following is the next step in managing the neonate?

options.label: B
options.text: Obtain a complete blood count and differential

options.label: D
options.text: Place the infant under a warmer

questions.correct_answer: D. Place the infant under a warmer

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to urology OPD by his father with a complaint of increased penile size and excessive pubic hair . Upon further investigation, his three younger brothers have no history of similar issues. On examination, bilateral testicular enlargement is evident. A comprehensive hormonal evaluation showed an elevated serum testosterone value (4.0 nmol/L) and a prepubertal gonadotropin hormone value. What is the most common cause of peripheral precocious puberty in males ?

A 15-year-old boy comes with his parents to the hospital with reports showing > +2 S.D height during childhood , and the parents complain that the child did not gain height after that . Which of the following conditions is not associated with tall stature during childhood but normal adult height?

A 32-year-old male presented in the ENT outpatient department with a complaint of pain in the left ear with fluid discharge and decreased hearing over the last 6 months. On otoscopic examination, the patient has purulent discharge with large central perforation. The patient was prescribed antibiotics and did not respond. After failure to initial medical antibiotic treatment, the patient is recommended for surgical option and will most likely undergo surgery next week. Based on the given information, the surgical procedure will likely involve one of the following structures?

A 25-year-old woman comes to the ENT outpatient department complaining of hearing loss and unsteadiness while standing and walking for the past 2 months. She needs to support herself against a wall to avoid falling. The patient has not had any recent injuries and has no history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an unsteady gait. She sways when asked to stand upright with her feet together. She cannot hear fingers rubbing next to her ears or repeat words whispered in her ears. MRI revealed the below image. Which of the following is the earliest reflex to be lost in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Nerve Involvement
Vth nerve:
  • Earliest nerve to be involved.
  • Reduced corneal sensitivity, numbness, or face paraesthesia- loss of corneal reflex.
  • Involvement of this nerve indicates that the tumour is roughly 2.5 cm in diameter and occupies the cerebellopontine angle.
VIIth nerve:
  • Sensory fibres are affected by early hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall (Hitzelberger’s sign), loss of taste (as tested by electrogustometry), and reduced lacrimation on the Schirmer test.
  • Motor fibres are more resistant and are affected late. A delayed blink reflex may be an early manifestation.
IXth & Xth nerves:
  • Dysphagia and hoarseness due to palatal, pharyngeal, and laryngeal paralysis.
Other symptoms
Brain stem
  • Ataxia, weakness, and numbness of arms and legs with exaggerated tendon reflexes.
Cerebellum
  • Dysdiadochokinesia, ataxic gait, nystagmus
Raised ICT
  • Headache, nausea, vomiting, diplopia & papilledema with the blurring of vision.

questions.text: A neonate during the 1 st week of life presents to the clinic with excessive watering and ropy mucous discharge in the conjunctival sac. On examination, the following structure is found to involve, as shown below: Which of the following describes correct about the direction of the involved structure?

A 65 years old diabetic from low socioeconomic status came to your ENT OPD with complaints of bad breath from the nose for 2 days. She does not complaint of any fever. She reports that she is non-compliant with her medications. Her diabetes is not controlled. Nasal endoscopy revealed below depicted image: Which of the following is the best treatment?

A 10-year-old male presented to the ENT outpatient department due to recurrent upper respiratory infections with denasal speech and was diagnosed as a case of chronic adenoid hypertrophy. The patient underwent adenoidectomy. He returns for the follow-up with the complaint of fluid leakage through the nose while eating. Which of the following complications is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?

A 37-year-old female presents to the ENT department with a hoarse voice for the past few days . She also has occasional gastric reflux symptoms and a constant desire to clear her throat. On laryngoscopy following finding is seen: Which of the following is incorrect regarding her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Unilateral & over the vocal process of arytenoids

options.label: C
options.text: Speech therapy to correct the pitch of voice

options.label: D
options.text: Intralesional injection of steroid is given to correct inflammation and size of granuloma

questions.correct_answer: B. Throat pain improves on phonation

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a complaint of epistaxis. After a series of treatments, the bleeding could not be stopped. His medical history is consistent with hypertension and diabetes. His medications include metformin and amlodipine. An attempt to block the external carotid artery is made which does not lead to resolution of the bleeding. Which of the following artery is responsible for the bleeding in this case?

A 78-year-old female a known case of hypertension and uncontrolled diabetes mellitus for 15 years presents in the OPD with the complaint of otalgia (ear pain) and greenish-black discharge. On examination, the patient has tenderness over the temporal region. On otoscopy, she has multiple granulations in the external auditory canal. The culture of the discharge turns out to be Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?

A 3-year-old child is brought to your clinic by his mother . The mother says the child complains of a foreign body sensation in his eyes and dry eye s , and she has noticed the redness of his eyes for the past two weeks . His diet is poor in fruits and vegetables. His best-corrected visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes, with normal motility and fundus. Slit-lamp examination show s keratinisation of the temporal and nasal conjunctiva with bilateral b itot spots . Which of the following is the best treatment for this child?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral vitamin A 1 lakh units for 0, 1, 28 days

options.label: B
options.text: IM vitamin A 1 lakh unit s for 0, 1, 28 days

options.label: C
options.text: Oral vitamin A 1 lakh unit s for 0, 1, 14 days

options.label: D
options.text: IM vitamin A 1 lakh unit s for 0, 1, 14 days

questions.correct_answer: D. IM vitamin A 1 lakh unit s for 0, 1, 14 days

questions.text: A sixty-year-old male presents to your clinic with the complaint of blurry vision in his right eye for the past month. About a year ago, the patient underwent phacoemulsification surgery for cataract removal of the same eye. The defective vision was gradual in onset and was not associated with pain, redness or watering. According to the patient, his cataract surgery was uncomplicated, and his vision was perfect after surgery. The most common cause of this patient’s condition is?

A 22-year-old patient presents to the clinic complaining of itching and ocular pain. The examination of his eye shows the following findings: Which of the following is not a feature of the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 19-year-old female who was a victim of an acid attack was brought to the emergency department with complaints of severe facial pain. The pulse of the patient is 130 bpm. She is otherwise vitally stable. The was managed and stabilized. After initial stabilization, the damages were evaluated, and there was extensive ocular damage. Which of the following facts is true about the injury involved in this case?

options.label: C
options.text: Steroids are used for initial management

options.label: D
options.text: Glaucoma is the most preventable complication following the acid injury

questions.correct_answer: D. Glaucoma is the most preventable complication following the acid injury

questions.text: A 44-year-old male was referred to your clinic because of pain, redness, and elevated eye pressure in the right eye. The patient also gave a history of four similar episodes, in which he had the same symptoms and his eye pressure was elevated. The most likely diagnosis is:

A 5-month-old infant presents to the ophthalmology OPD with cloudy eyes since birth. On examination, the infant is not visually aware of the surrounding environment. Her eyes appear as shown in the image below. Which of the following does not cause this condition?

A 26-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of a slowly enlarging painless mass in front of her neck. She further gives the history that this mass had grown over a three-year period. She has the sensation that food is getting stuck in her upper throat, and she easily feels fatigued. He is vitally stable, and the examination of reveals that the swelling has multiple nodules. The thyroid ultrasound revealed Grave’s disease. If the patient has eye involvement with the progression of the disease, then which of the following will be affected first?

A 28-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with a complaint of blurry vision, decreased visual acuity, redness, and floaters in both eyes. There is a vitreous cell found in both eyes on physical examination. The rest of the physical examination is normal. The vitals are within normal limits. What are the two tumours that can be considered in this patient which are commonly associated with this condition?

A 7 -year-old boy presents to the clinic with the complaint of fever, runny nose, and cough for the past three days . The boy also has a rash over his body . The mother reports that the boy first developed a fever and runny nose a few days ago. Today she noticed a rash, as shown below: Which of the following term best describes the skin findings in the patient?

A 59-year-old woman presents to the dermatologic clinic to evaluate her skin lesions . She states that it has been present for several years and is not associated with other symptoms. On examination following lesion is noted as shown below : Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 2-year-old boy presented to the office by his parents with a skin rash for 2 weeks. He was born out of a consanguineous marriage and had a history of the collodion membrane. Vital signs are normal. On examination, he had large, thick, plate-like brown scaling in a generalized distribution; no erythroderma and ectropion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
ICHTHYOSIS VULGARIS X LINKED ICHTHYOSIS LAMELLAR ICHTHYOSIS
AD XLR AR
Def. of filaggrin Def. of steroid sulphatase enzyme Def. of transglutaminase-1 enzyme

Fine scales

Extensors mainly involved

Winter exacerbation

Thick brown hyperkeratosis

Flexors spared

Birth complications

Larger thick brown plate-like hyperkeratosis

The whole body involved' Collodion membrane/ baby

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought by his mother after she noticed a dry, red patch on his back thirty minutes ago. He gives a history of an itchy rash that started on his shoulders that later spread to his trunk. He also added a history of sore throat 2 weeks ago. On examination, there are erythematous scaly papules and plaques, as shown in the picture: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
